args: Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" . Judge denies temporary ban on DOGE access to private data A federal judge on Friday denied a request to temporarily ban employees working with the U.S. DOGE Service from accessing closely guarded systems inside the federal government that contain tax returns, Social Security numbers and reams of private data for millions of Americans. But another federal court’s temporary ban remains in place for now. The lawsuit filed in the Eastern District of Virginia by the nonprofit Electronic Privacy Information Center and an anonymous federal worker is one of several seeking to block DOGE, which stands for Department of Government Efficiency, from getting ahold of records kept by the Treasury’s Bureau of the Fiscal Service, which processes about $6 trillion a year in electronic payments to households, businesses and other recipients — and keeps vast stores of data on “virtually every single person in the country,” according to the plaintiffs. Attorneys also asked the judge to block DOGE from accessing records maintained by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), which detail the Social Security numbers, birth dates, salaries, home addresses and disciplinary histories of all federal workers and personal information for millions of applicants seeking government jobs. DOGE’s flurry of moves in the first month of the new presidential administration have sparked dozens of lawsuits across the country. In a written opinion Friday, U.S. District Judge Rossie D. Alston Jr. said the nonprofit and the federal worker seeking a preliminary injunction had “not provided concrete evidence that Defendants are actively misusing or even attempting to misuse their sensitive data.” A federal court in Manhattan already had imposed a temporary ban on DOGE access to Americans’ private data held by the Treasury, and other requests for temporary bans are pending before a federal judge in D.C. Alston was appointed by President Donald Trump during his first term. “Plaintiffs’ fears of future harm are much too speculative and would require the Court to make several leaps in reasoning in order to warrant injunctive relief,” Alston wrote. John L. Davisson, director of litigation for the Electronic Privacy Information Center, said at a hearing Friday that exposing millions of Americans’ private financial data in a “historically large and consequential breach” violated several federal laws and the Fifth Amendment, and could leave the United States more vulnerable to malign actors. In one of his first executive orders last month, Trump charged DOGE and its de facto leader, billionaire Elon Musk, with modernizing government agencies and reviewing their functions. Justice Department attorneys said in a legal filing that the groups suing over DOGE’s moves were “seeking unprecedented judicial micromanagement of the Executive Branch’s ability to share government data with its own employees.” Jonathan Lucier, an assistant U.S. attorney in Virginia, said at a court hearing Friday that the employees in question were all hired by Treasury and OPM or detailed to those agencies. Granting data access to in-house employees carrying out a presidential initiative “cannot be illegal,” Lucier argued. Tom Krause, a tech company chief executive who briefly worked for DOGE, is now a senior Treasury adviser and the only liaison to the group. Justice Department attorneys said in court papers that he has never been given “direct access” to the Bureau of the Fiscal Service payment system, only “over-the-shoulder” access “to review activity others performed in the system or data others accessed from the system.” But Justice Department attorneys acknowledged in a footnote that another employee who began working at DOGE and was then hired by Treasury, Marko Elez, did have access to the closely guarded payment system — which includes details of highly classified programs — until he resigned Feb. 6. He was found to have made racist statements on social media. Musk said he would rehire Elez, who now works at the Social Security Administration, according to Bloomberg News. In response to a lawsuit filed by 19 states, another federal court barred Krause from accessing Americans’ personal or financial information pending further legal proceedings. U.S. District Judge Paul A. Engelmayer in Manhattan found that the states would face irreparable harm without the temporary ban “because of the risk that the new policy presents of the disclosure of sensitive and confidential information and the heightened risk that the systems in question will be more vulnerable than before to hacking.” Another federal judge in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction in that case Friday, prohibiting DOGE from accessing the Treasury data while the states’ lawsuit is pending. U.S. District Judge Jeannette A. Vargas said she could lift the ban if the Trump administration can show it is taking steps to safeguard the public’s most sensitive data.
